dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s 2:00 a.m. in a major New York law firm. Ten floors of office space in the heart of the Sixth Avenue Canyon. Seven hours from now this place will be vibrating with th beehive energy of six hundred attorneys and their attenda staff, but for the moment it is a vast, empty, half-lit shell. A SERIES OF SHOTS emphasizing the size and power o this organization; shots that build quietly to the idea t somewhere here -- somewhere in this building -- there’s something very important going on. MUSIC and CREDITS alre mixing with the crazed, manic, express train chatter of -

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...-Michael. Dear, Michael. Nurse Michael. Dr. Clayton. Secret Hero. Keeper of the Hidden Sins. Of course it’s you. Who else could they send? Who else could be trusted? Smoke on the horizon -- hole in the bucket -- voices crying from Milwaukee to Manhattan, “Where’s our hero?” “Where’s our Cleanser Of The Hidden Sins?” And here you are, sleeves rolled up, lips sealed -- broom -- dustbin -- bankroll at the ready! Fifties, is it still fifties? When you came to Boston, you remember? God, you must’ve had a thousand of them! The cash -- the smile -- the quiet word in the corner -- of course it’s you, Michael, who else could it ever be? But Michael, please, before you sweep, please just hear me out -- just try -- because it’s not like Boston -- it’s not an episode -- relapse -- fuck up -- I’m begging you, Michael, make believe it’s not just madness, because it’s not just madness -- (continuing, as--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A XEROX MACHINE -- cranking out high-speed copies -- ten pages a second flashing before our eyes -- all informatio a blur except for the letterhead which is constant:

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEYS AT LAW
dialogues.text: As...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I mean, yes -- okay, yes -- elements of madness -- the speed of madness -- yes, the occasional, euphoric, pseudo- hallucinatory moments that, yes -- fine -- agreed -- distracting -- nostalgic -- all of that -- (continuing, as--) A HUGE EMPTY OFFICE BULLPEN. CUBICLES AND WORKSTATIONS.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- but that’s just the package -- the plate -- think of it as a tax -- The Mania Tax -- The Insanity Tax -- or like advertising on TV -- it’s the freight -- the weight -- it’s the price of the show -- A LONG, DARK CORRIDOR. A CLEANING CREW IN THE DISTANCE.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- just please, just hear me out, Michael, because I swear to you, this is so much, so very much more, than the ravings of some hypo-maniacal, bipolar attorney --

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- Two weeks ago I came out of the building -- I’m running across Sixth Avenue -- there’s a car waiting -- I have exactly thirty-eight minutes to get to Laguardia,and I’m dictating -- there’s this frantic associate running to keep up --

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- we’‘re in the middle of the street -- the light changes -- the traffic -- unleashed -- it’s coming -- serious traffic -- but there I am -- I’m babbling -- my mouth -- I can’t stop -- some ridiculous, involuntary part of my brain just keeps going -- I’m standing there dictating this trade secret, Motion to Suppress...  AN OFFICE PHONE. TWELVE LINES BLINKING IN THE DARK.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...and there, Michael, in the middle of Sixth Avenue -- as I stood there jabbering -- and this poor young woman is screaming -- traffic speeding toward us -- I looked at my hands and my suit -- my briefcase -- and it came to me -- came over me -- through me -- the overwhelming sensation -- the feeling -- the fact -- that I was covered with some sort of film -- an oil -- an ooze -- my hair -- my face -- like a glaze -- a coating -- and at first I thought, “My God, I know what this is, this is some sort of amniotic, embryonic fluid -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - I’m drenched in afterbirth -- I’ve breached the chrysalis -- I’ve been reborn.” --

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- but the traffic -- this stampede -- cars -- trucks -- the horns -- the screaming associate -- I’m thinking, “No -- reset -- this cannot be rebirth. If anything, this must some giddy illusion of renewal that happens in the final instant before death.” --

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- and then -- in the fraction of a moment it took for that idea to form -- I realized all of that was wrong, because I looked back at the building and had the most stunning moment of clarity...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...I realized, Michael, at that moment, that I had emerged -- as I have done nearly every day for the past twenty- eight years of my life -- not through doors of Kenner, Bach & Ledeen --

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- not through the portals of our huge and powerful law firm, but rather from the asshole of an organism whose sole function is to excrete the poison -- the ammo -- the defoliant -- necessary for even larger and more dangerous organisms to destroy the miracle of humanity --

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- and that I have been coated with this patina of shit for the better part of my life and that the stink and stain might in all likelihood take the rest of my days to undo --

dialogues.speaker: TROLLEY TOWARD BIG DOORS AT THE END OF THE HALL --
dialogues.text: ARTHUR EDEN’S (V.0.) -- and do you know what I did next? I took a deep, cleansing breath. I set that notion aside. I tabled it. I said to myself, “As clear as this may be -- as potent as this may feel -- as true a thing as I believe I have witnessed here -- I must wait. It must stand the test of time.”

dialogues.speaker: AN ATTORNEY HUDDLED OVER HIS MOBILE PHONE, SEEING THE KID
dialogues.text: COMING, HELPING HIM BY OPENING THE DOORS, as --

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: (kneeling, whispering) I’ve got that cunt from the Wall Street Journal on line eight. I told her you were in Bermuda, but I’d try to patch you in... MARTY BACH looks up from his papers. He’s seventy. It’s his name on the door. Big power. Sweet eyes. A thousand neckties. A velvet switchblade.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (punching up line eight) Marty Bach. How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (PHONE/OVER)
dialogues.text: “Marty, hi, it’s Bridget Klein. Look, we're going with a story tomorrow about a settlement in the U/North defoliant case. You want to comment?”

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: The case you’re referring to, is now, as it has been for the past six years, pending and unresolved. Until our client has their day in court or the plaintiffs come to their senses and drop the suit, I’1l have nothing of value to tell you. BARRY kneeling there, hanging on every word --

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (PHONE/OVER)
dialogues.text: “Come on, Marty, Barry’s telling me you’re off at some conference. I know for a fact you’re in the office right now with like six hundred people trying to push this thing through.”

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Here’s what I know: your deadline was twenty minutes ago, so either you’re fishing for a story or trying to get out of writing a retraction. In either case, I wish you well...best of luck... (as he hangs up--) -.-Sweet dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY

dialogues.text: KAREN CROWDER sitting fully dressed on the john. She is Senior In-House Counsel for the largest agricultural/chem supply manufacturer on the planet. She is hiding here. Sh is trying to fight off a panic attack using a breathing exercise she read about in an airline magazine. As we hea

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR EDENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...even this, Michael -- even now -- that you’re here -- there’s a reason, a reason it’s you -- every reason -- surely you can sense that -- how it pulls together -- how it gathers -- Nurse Michael -- Secret Hero -- Keeper of the Hidden Sins -- tell me you can see that, Michael, for God’s sake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL CLAYTON’S FACE -- A PHOTOGRAPH laminated onto a Kenner, Bach & Ledeen ID card -- FILLS OUR FRAME. It’s a man’s face. Son of a second-generation cop’s face. Father of a ten-year-old boy’s face. A face women like more than they know why. The good soldier’s face. THE ID CARD just one of several objects sitting at the bottom of a shitty plastic basket. Also here: one roll of breath mints, two mobile phones, business cards, too many keys on a Mercede security pendant keychain, and one heavy-duty steel Rolex

Only one of the roo ten tables is lit tonight. In the background, a Cantonese Announcer calling the first race at Happy Valley and -- MICHAEL CLAYTON glancing at his four hole cards. dialogues.text: (peeling off twenties) Half the pot. Two hundred. PLAYER #4, a Chinese landlord -- already pushing his card away -- he’s folding --

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: (back to Michael) Two hundred to you. MICHAEL shakes his head. He’s out. PLAYER #2 right behind him. THE DEALER starts gathering cards for the next hand.

dialogues.text: You don’t remember me, huh? (to Michael as he rakes in the pot--) We played a couple times that lamp place. On Bowery. That guy’s showroom. All the lamps and shit?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Galaxy.

dialogues.text: (just ignoring him) Cause that was a good location.

dialogues.text: THE BASKET WITH MICHAEL’S STUFF. THE PAGER starts vibrati A moment later, THE CELL PHONE starts ringing and --

dialogues.text: Ascending. MICHAEL leaving in a hurry. Strapping on his Rolex, trying to read the pager and --

dialogues.text: -- is he drunk?

dialogues.text: (nervous, hyper) “-- no, that’s the first thing I asked him -- no, he’s sober --”

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: -- tell him to stay off the phone --

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: “-- so, Michael, I mean, you’re on it now, right? Because this guy, he’s a huge client -- this is half my book, this guy, okay?”

dialogues.text: THE DAMAGED FRONT BODY PANEL OF A MERCEDES. Dented in. MICHAEL’S HAND -- his pen -- examining the freshly-chippe paint, until --  10 MICHAEL stands. We see him now. The Mercedes just one of half-a-dozen luxury vehicles lined up here in this bright oversized garage.

dialogues.text: Mega kitchen. The scale and taste of real wealth.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: (pacing) What they did, you see, they changed the grade there. They widened the street, I’m sure someone told them they were making an improvement... MICHAEL on a stool at the island. MRS. GREER standing by herself. Nightgown pulled tight. Her second tumbler of Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: But now, you see, when it rains? With this new angle, and they put these new these sodium lamps -- it’s blinding, that turn there. Just blinding.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: They’11l have to take a look at that.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: And this, it’s not just tonight. I’ve been saying this for years. (to his wife) How many times have we talked about that corner? Gen? MRS. GREER silent. Numb.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Greer, we don’t have a great deal of time to work with here. MR. GREER’s anxiety sharpening. Arrogance under siege.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: So the circumstances, road conditions, none of this holds any interest for you?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What interests me right now is finding the strongest criminal attorney that can get here in the next fifteen minutes.  11

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: (bristling) Well, that sounds ominous...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: We have some good relationships up here in Westchester.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: So what are you? You’re not a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Not the kind you need.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: What kind is that?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You need a trial lawyer. Someone to see this all the way through. That’s not what I do. There it is. And MR. GREER doesn’t like it one bit.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: I think we’re gonna need to pull Walter back in on this. (like it’s some kind of business meeting) I want to get him back on the phone, get him into the mix. Because, I’1l be frank, I’m not sure I like the way this is going.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Sir... (cut the crap) We don’t have time for Walter. Your options here, they’re gonna get smaller very quickly.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: What options? I’m not hearing any options.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m suggesting you go local. I’m telling you there’s several people up here I like for this.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: And that’s it? That’s what you’ve got? (to his wife) You believe this? )

dialogues.speaker: E

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Greer, you left the scene of an accident on a slow weeknight, six miles from the State Police barracks. Believe me, if there’s a line, you're right up front.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: I can get a lawyer any time I want! You think I need you for that? You think we’re sitting here forty-five minutes waiting for a goddam referral?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t know what Walter promised you, but whatever it w--

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: “Miracle Worker.” (cutting him cold) That’s a direct quote. That’s Walter twenty minutes ago, okay? “Hang tight, I’m sending you a miracle worker!”

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well, he misspoke.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: About what? That you’re the firm’s fixer? Or that you’re any good at it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GREER
dialogues.text: Elliot...

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: This guy was running in the street! (losing it) You add the lights -- the rain -- the angle -- what kind of person’s out running in the street in the rain at midnight? Answer me th-- (stopping instantly, as--) GLASS SHATTERS! -- MRS. GREER just hurled her highball in the sink. Staring at her husband. Silence, until --  13

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER
dialogues.text: What if someone had stolen the car? Happens all the time. (dead air) Hypothetically... This awful pause. MICHAEL wielding the silence like a clu

dialogues.text: Cops like hit and run cases. They work them hard and they clear them fast. Right now, there’s a BCI unit picking paint chips off a guardrail. Tomorrow morning they’re gonna be looking for the owner of a custom- color, hand-rubbed, green Mercedes SL 500. This guy you hit, if he got a look at the plate, it won’t even take that long. Like that -- THE PHONE RINGS -- harsh -- sudden --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GREER
dialogues.text: ...omigod...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (ignoring the phone) There’s no play here. There’s no angle. There’s no champagne room. And I’m not a miracle worker, I’ma janitor. So the math on this is simple: the smaller the mess, the easier it is for me to clean up. THE PHONE STILL RINGING and --

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREER

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No. They don’t call. (calmly picking up--) Hello? (beat) Jerry. Hey, it’s Michael... (pause) Yeah, sorry. I’m in the neighborhood. You got a pen? MICHAEL on hold. Silence now. MR. AND MRS. GREER parked like glaciers. Broken glass in the sink.  14

dialogues.text: One hour later. MICHAEL leaning on the MERCEDES, munching on a loaf of stale French bread. Looking over, as JERRY DANTE, local criminal attorney, comes out of the house --

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: He’s changing his shirt... (as he arrives) I talked to my guy at the State Police barracks. Better we go over there and surrender and they can tell the town cops to kiss off. This kid he hit, he’s a waiter at one of those clubs along the strip there. He’s stable. I guess they’re putting some pins in his hip. Good news is he got busted selling pot last year, so we got something to work with anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You don’t need me for this, right?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Couldn’t hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I‘1l have somebody call you. JERRY nods. Okay. But lingering a moment, because --

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL

dialogues.speaker: JERRY

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: And don’t worry about this... (re: Mr. Greer) I‘11 put my back into it. MICHAEL nods. Heading for the car and --  15

dialogues.text: MICHAEL driving. Escaping. Running from more than Mr. Gre and Jerry Dante. More than just a bad night boiling behin his eyes. Driving hard and wild. Turning suddenly and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL -- turning again -- aimless -- windows open -- cold air whipping through -- braking suddenly -- impulsiv -- turning -- suddenly -- faster now and --

THE MERCEDES speeding toward us -- climbing around the tu eating up the valley road that runs along the pasture -- suddenly the car is slowing -- braking hard and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL pulling to a stop. Staring out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL getting out of the car. Standing there. THREE HORSES poised at the crest of the pasture. Hanging there in the fog like ghosts. MICHAEL jumping the fence. Walking slowly into the field. Behind him, the MERCEDES with the engine running. THE HORSES aware of him now. Watching him come. MICHAEL’S FACE as he walks. And later on we’1ll understan all the forces roiling inside him, but for the moment, th simplest thing to say is that this is a man who needs mor  16 than anything to see one pure, natural thing, and by some miracle has found his way to this place. The wet grass an cold air and no coat -- none of it makes any difference t him right now -- he’s a pilgrim stumbling into the cathed And he stops. Just standing there. Empty. Open. Lost. Nothing but the field and the fog and the woods beyond. THE HORSES staring at him. MICHAEL staring back. And just like that...

dialogues.speaker: THE MERCEDES EXPLODES
dialogues.text: THE HORSES already running before MICHAEL can turn back - pieces of the car that have been blown into the sky still raining down before he’s fully grasped what’s happening - MICHAEL simply shocked. Senseless. Standing there frozen. Stunned. What just happened? The car -- his car -- is gon -- just like that. MICHAEL looks around. Looks back. He should be dead. He is not. When THE GAS TANK EXPLODES! And suddenly it’s clear. All that staggered chaos in Michael’s eyes suddenly replaced with steel. He should be dead. He is not. And now he’s walking. Toward the car. Walking faster. Determined. And suddenly he’s running -- running toward the fire. Faster and faster, as we...

dialogues.text: (into his microphone) “Roger that. Let’s keep a radio check every five, okay?” INT. ELEVATOR LANDING/ARTHUR’S LOFT -~- NIGHT (CONT) A downtown building. IKER standing at the door to Arthur’ loft. Backpack. Tool kit. Same radio/cellphone rig. Gloved hands, already starting to work the lock, as --  54

dialogues.speaker: IKER
dialogues.text: (into his microphone) “Every five. Roger that.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean, slick bachelor decor. MICHAEL with a towel wrapped his waist, sits at the edge of the bed, speed dialing a mobile phone. The sheets with an apres-sex chaos about th ARTHUR’S VOICE (his answering machine) “You've reached Arthur. If you wish to leave a message, please do so after the tone.” MICHAEL hangs up before the beep.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI, (0S)
dialogues.text: (from the kitchen) You want me to heat it up?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (calling back) Doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRINI GLASS -- the young lawyer we met in the elevator at Kenner, Bach -- is busy reheating a Chinese takeout dinne that was obviously interrupted earlier. She’s wearing nothing but one of Michael’s shirts. It’s a modern, one-bedroom apartment in a high-rise that towers over Columbus Avenue. The kitchen open to the livi room. Windows to Central Park and The Westside twenty stories below. A slick pad. Small but clean, furnished efficiently, and the view is sharp. BRINI starts the microwave. There’s a roach in an ashtray on the counter. She lights it. Taking a drag, as MICHAEL wanders in from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: (the joint) You want? He waves it off. Coming around behind her. Kissing her neck as he moves to the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Now you're hungry...  55

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: I know. There’s an open bottle of white wine. He’s pouring.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You never told me you were working with Jeff Gaffney.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: It’s just a project. (pulling plates from the cupboard--) He hates you. You know that, right?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: There’s a heartbreaker.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: You helped him out, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Jeff Gaffney hates everyone.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: What did you do for him?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don’t even remember.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: That is such bullshit... He just smiles. She tries the wine. Some subtle tension pulling at her. And the dope didn’t get her where she wanted.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: I watch these people. At the office. How they relate to you. I can always tell, or I think I can anyway, the ones that you’ve done something for.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Half of them don’t even know I work there.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: Or they’re pretending to ignore you, or else they’re super polite...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Or they hate me.  He looks at her. She looks away.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: I never know what you know or don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Try me.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: They offered me London. (awkward beat) Or did you know that already?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No. I didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: I wasn’t sure.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: So this is the merger.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you don’t know all this. (trying to laugh it off--) Well, there you go... I’m blown. There’s my big secret.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I thought I was your secret.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: Really? I always thought it was the other way around. The microwave starts beeping.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I was gonna say when were you gonna tell me, but I guess that’s what you’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: I really thought you knew. MICHAEL looks away. Something catching his eye.

dialogues.speaker: THERE ON THE COUNTER
dialogues.text: “REALM AND CONQUEST.” Book One. The red cover. picking it up. A momentary distraction. 56

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: I haven’t decided yet either. (trying a smile) Seriously. Nothing’s been decided. She’s waiting for him to answer. He hesitates. Puts the book down.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Jeff Gaffney’s wife starts this affair with their contractor in East Hampton. It takes about a month, the guy realizes she’s crazy, he tries to break it off. She gets drunk. She drives out to his house, takes a road flare and tries to torch his truck. She’s just so fucked up she doesn’t see the two Dominican kids sleeping in the garage. One guy it turned out okay. The other one needed a lot of help. Was that a gift or a bomb? Neither of them sure.

dialogues.speaker: BRINI
dialogues.text: Jesus... (staring at him) How do you make something like that disappear? (off his silence) I guess you don’t. MICHAEL drains his wine. Pouring another, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR marching through the night. Same glorious smile. Just another madman loose in Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DIGITAL CAMERA LCD SCREEN. THE IMAGE -- an overhead sho of a coffee table cluttered with magazines, newspapers an junk mail. THE DIGITAL CAMERA is sitting on THE ACTUAL COFFEE TABLE. IKER, wearing gloves and a hair net, is very precisely an quickly searching through the debris. A consummate professional at work. As he proceeds, he keeps checking t camera image to make sure every object is returned to its original position. This is raw space. A box. High ceilings. Industrial windows along one wall. Half-assed groupings of furniture define the space: Bed and dresser, desk and computer,  58 bathroom and closets framed out along the far walls. The decor is odd. Half the stuff is clearly from a previo life; Eastside antiques, proper rugs, generic oil landsca piled carelessly around. Above all this, the clutter of Arthur’s recent manic acquisitions -- books, papers, foun objects, curios -- as if a layer of madness were blanketi the landscape of his old life. IKER MOVING THROUGH THE LOFT -- eyes scanning -- barely reacting as -- THE PHONE RINGS -- and he begins to hear: ARTHUR’S VOICE (on the answering machine) “If you wish to leave a message, please do so after the tone.” (beep, and then--)

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (through the machine) Arthur, look, I’ve been calling all day, if you’re there, please for crissake just pick up and talk to me... (continuing as--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRINI alone in bed. Deep asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (PHONE/OVER)
dialogues.text: No? Yes? Shit, come on, man... (a weary beat) Arthur, listen to me, I’m leaving my phone on -- we have to talk... (continuing, as--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL in the dark with the phone and a new bottle of wi

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: ...what happened this morning -- yesterday morning -- whatever it is -- forget it, okay? Someday we’ll laugh about it, right? But you gotta get back to me here, okay? And soon. (about to hang up, when--) Arthur, look...I‘’11 tell you what -- because you said it yourself -- part of this is definitely madness, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR walking. VERNE somewhere back there --  59

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (PHONE/OVER)
dialogues.text: ...There’s a chemical part of this, and you know it, and I know it, and if you're ready to start with that, then I’m more than willing to meet you halfway and cop to the fact that, yes, the situation sucks. The case sucks. U/North sucks. We can start with that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IKER with the medicine cabinet open. There must be forty prescriptions jammed in here and he’s checking every sing one, as he listens to --

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (on the answering machine) ...-You hear me, Arthur? Pick up the goddam phone. (silence) I’m telling you you’re right, okay? About what we are. I’m saying you’re crazy -- the behavior’s completely out of control -- but you’re right. You called it. We’re janitors. Okay? I_get it...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: ...but we came to this, Arthur, we had choices. It didn’t just happen overnight. You can’t just suddenly say, “Hey, sorry. Game over. I’m into miracles now.” (suddenly) Goddamit, Arthur, pick up the fucking phone and talk to me! Whatever the hell else you think is so important right now, you better let me help you on this, because I’m telling you straight up here, janitor to janitor, I don’t see anybody else with a broom on the horizon. (one last hopeful pause, before, “beep”--)

dialogues.speaker: MACHINE VOICE
dialogues.text: “The answering disc is currently full. Please try your call again later.” MICHAEL left hanging. He puts down the phone. Drains his wine glass. Stands at the window.  60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR walking through the neon canyon. Bathing in the miracle of it all. His eyes seem locked open, gathering stimuli faster than the speed of light. Every moment -- every beatific instant -- has a purpose. Everything is fu for the significance turbine spinning inside him. He slow his pace, hesitates for a moment and --

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: DIAMOND VISION BILLBOARD -- a familiar logo -- u/north we grow your world together

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold, rural Wisconsin. A tired old room in a tired old house. A WALL PHONE RINGING. BIG SISTER, the Farmer’s Wif hauling a baby on her hip as she moves to answer it. THE FARMER and YOUNG DAUGHTER sitting over breakfast in the B

dialogues.speaker: BIG SISTER
dialogues.text: (grabbing the phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR/ PHONE
dialogues.text: Is Anna there?

dialogues.speaker: BIG SISTER
dialogues.text: Hang on... (calling into the house) Where’s Anna? (continuing, as--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same time. A PANEL TRUCK parked here. It’s a scuffed-up, late model vehicle. Some half-assed electrical supply log buried beneath the graffiti. About as anonymous as it get

dialogues.speaker: BIG SISTER, (PHONE/OVER)
dialogues.text: “,..Anna! Where is she? ANNA!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise. Welcome to a perfect mobile, urban surveillance HQ. Ugly and state-of-the-art. Purely functional. Nothing Gucci about it. A cot. Tool cases. Cooler. Folding table.  61 Couple laptops. Space heater. IKER just now clambering in the back door. ERNE wearing headphones, already plugged i waving for him to hurry up --

dialogues.speaker: BIG SISTER, (PHONE/OVER)
dialogues.text: “-- Anna, you got a phone call!” VERNE flipping switches, pulling his laptop closer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNA KYSURSEN grabbing the phone as she comes by, pulling the cord as far as she can, making sure BIG SISTER is out earshot before she answers --

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (finally) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Anna? Hi. It’s Arthur...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Did you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR pacing with the phone --

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Did you think about what we said?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You didn’t tell anybody, did you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No. (eyes to the kitchen) My sister’s spying on me but that’s normal.  62

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Because I meant what I said.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I know, it’s just there’s like four- hundred and fifty people in this lawsuit, why are you choosing me?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’m crazy, right?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (laughing) That’s for sure...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Does it matter, Anna? I mean, really? Isn’t it? Isn’t that what you wait for?... ANNA smiles. No one’s ever spoken to her like this before

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: ...To find someone, and they’re like a lens and suddenly you’re looking through them and everything’s changed. Nothing can ever be the same again... (he’s rattling on, but--)

dialogues.speaker: BIG SISTER, (OS)
dialogues.text: (sharply, from behind) Who’re you talking to? ANNA wheels around. BIG SISTER standing in the pantry doo Sour look in her eye. Squirming kid on her hip.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: You’re gonna tie up the phone all night, we got a right to know.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It’s for me, okay? I get calls too! ANNA pulling the phone wire as far as it goes, disappeari into a back stairwell. Closing the door behind her, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. VERNE and IKER listening to the continuing conversation over headphones. AUDIO LIGHTS on the equipme rising and falling as Arthur and Anna keep talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZABEL eating breakfast. MICHAEL with just coffee. Big news.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I can get you twelve on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: ZABEL
dialogues.text: Twelve is weak. Twelve looks bad.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: How do you figure that?

dialogues.speaker: ZABEL
dialogues.text: They look at seventy-five. They look at you. They’re wondering what the problem is. Now you say twelve. That’s just gonna make people nervous.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Gabe, this was the day before yesterday, okay? Let me get my ducks in a row here.

dialogues.speaker: ZABEL
dialogues.text: What’s the car worth?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s a lease. It’s the firm’s.

dialogues.speaker: ZABEL
dialogues.text: So go to the bank. You got the apartment. You refinance.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I did that three months ago. A nasty pause. ZABEL with the polygraph stare.

dialogues.speaker: ZABEL
dialogues.text: You back at the tables?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, like I need the action. I don’t have enough going on. (the very idea) I hope you’re kidding.

dialogues.speaker: ZABEL
dialogues.text: He finds out you’re playing cards with his money. There’s no dialogue after that.  64

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: So much for Old Time’s Sake, huh?

dialogues.speaker: ZABEL
dialogues.text: Do everyone a favor. Get out the treasure map and start digging. You got a week. ZABEL goes back to his eggs. MICHAEL walks. INT. MARTY BACH’S TOWNHOUSE/FOYER -- DAY CINDY BACH leading MICHAEL in from the foyer. She’s late thirties. Pure trophy. Blonde, horsey, peppy.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (walk and talk) He’s been on the phone all morning. What else is new, right? TWO SIX-YEAR OLDS running wild in the background --

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Jamie! No running in the kitchen! (calling to some unseen babysitter--) Soroya! Are you watching them? (back to Michael) He’s upstairs, he’s taken over the living room... (pointing the way) Go for it. Soroya! (kids getting wilder in the background now--) Don’t you just love Saturday morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grand parlor floor. Everything perfect except for the TWO DOZEN DOCUMENT BOXES piled around the room. On the si of each box, the word EDENS and a number. MARTY poring ov paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Marty... MARTY turns back. Focuses.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You know what he’s doing? He’s making their case... (the boxes) I’m going through his files, I’m eee eT CMORE ) "  65 MARTY (cont'd) reading this...he’s building a case against U/North.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No one’s gonna let him do that.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Let him? (furious) Who’s gonna stop him? You know what I just heard? He’s calling these plaintiffs now -- this woman from the deposition? -- he’s calling these people -- he’s got these discovery documents stashed away here... (he’s stunned) It’s a fucking nightmare. I’ve been trying him all morning, you can’t even leave a message, he’s got the whole machine jammed up. MICHAEL watching him pull another bunch of files from a b

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (something on the floor) Is that his briefcase?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: We’ve been looking for it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It came up with all the stuff from his office. (lying effortlessly) You can’t believe the crap he’s got stashed away in here. MICHAEL nods. Accepting this. Plus there’s another agenda he’d like to get to here.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: So, Marty, look, I’m kind of ina spot here. (Marty focuses) I need a loan. I need eighty grand. MARTY hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I thought you were done with all that.  66

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s not the cards. Nothing like that. It’s the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Eighty thousand?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to jump you like this. I’ve been trying to get a meeting with you alone now for two weeks. (just going for it) And I know about the merger. Whether I’m supposed to know or not.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Nothing’s final.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: That’s why I’m asking now. You’re my meal ticket, Marty. I mean, let’s face it, once this is out of your hands, I’m screwed. You'll be cashed out and I’1l be staring at Barry and a bunch of strangers trying to explain what the hell it is I do.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Everybody knows how valuable you are, Michael. Everybody who needs to know.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I‘m forty-five. I’m broke. I’ve been riding shotgun for twelve years and I still don’t have any equity. Excuse me if I don’t feel reassured.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Nobody told you to go into the bar business.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I only opened the place so I'd have a way out.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I had no idea you were so unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: C’mon, Marty... (pushing down his temper) How many times have I asked you to let me get back on a litigation team. How many times?  67

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Anybody can go to court. You think that’s so special?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I was good at it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: So what? So are a lot of people. At this -- what you do -- at this, you’re great. For crissake, Michael, you have what everybody wants; you have a niche. You made a place, you made this niche for yourself. And if it’s nostalgia -- “Oh, you should’ve seen me when I was a D.A. back in Queens.” -- then let me give you a serious piece of advice: Leave it there. God forbid you’re not as good as you remember. Because I’ve seen that happen too.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: But I didn’t come for advice, did I?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: So this is what? Quid pro quo?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I give you the loan or you don’t help out with Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I never said that.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Maybe you should. Because this... (Arthur’s papers) This is cancer. This is something we don’t get it reined-in and cleaned up soon, everything’s vulnerable. Everything.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What’re you telling me?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: That I’m counting on you. (the grand gesture) I’m telling you that by this time next week Arthur will be under control

dialogues.speaker: MORE
dialogues.text: 68 MARTY (cont'd) and everyone who needs to, will have been reminded of your infinite value.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Jesus, Marty... MARTY suddenly smiling. Good cheer blossoming.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: When the fuck did you get so delicate? MICHAEL left hanging, no chance to respond, because here THE KIDS -- running up the stairs -- SQUEALING AND SCREAM -- chasing each other into the room and --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: -- there you are! -- (making a playful grab--) -- into the lion’s den! -- gotcha! -- MICHAEL standing there rocked, as MARTY starts roaring at the kids and they start squealing even louder and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BUILDING DIRECTORY. Five apartments. One per floor. Five names -- one of them EDENS. Buzzer. Intercom. MICHAEL pressing the buzzer for the umpteenth time. And again. And nothing. He tries the door. And it’s loose. But then he stops. Stepping back. Fuck it. Glancing back up to the third floor windows as he crosses the street and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERNE alone at the console --

dialogues.speaker: IKER, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: “-- here comes that guy again -- just passing you now --” There -- ON ONE OF THE LAPTOPS -- MICHAEL jogging past so low-res surveillance camera as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A minute later. HENRY reading as MICHAEL gets back in.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just call Uncle Gene and get the cops to help you?  69

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s not that kind of problem.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How much longer are we doing this?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half hour later. THE MERCEDES cruising Tribeca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. THE MERCEDES double parked. MICHAEL walking back to the car. Another dead-end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL driving. Scanning. HENRY’s patience has thinned.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: If we’re not gonna get to the movies why don’t you just say so. (beat) I want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hang on, Henry -- (something they just passed--) MICHAEL whips the car to the curb --

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (already jumping out--) -- stay right here -- lock the doors -- I’1ll be right back -- don’t move! --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL up the sidewalk to the alley --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR walking away.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (jogging after him) Arthur! Arthur! Wait up! ARTHUR stops. Turns. Caught. In his arms he’s cradling twenty-five fresh baguettes.  70

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Whoaa... (almost losing his loaves--) Michael. Jesus. You scared me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Making a delivery?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: No... (smiling) Very funny. Nothing like that... (as if it were all completely natural and needed no further explanation--) Have one...go on...really... (offering) It’s still warm. Best bread I’ve ever had in my life. MICHAEL suddenly holding warm French bread.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: So welcome home.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I know. The hotel. I’m sorry. I was getting a little overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: But you’re feeling better now?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yes. Definitely. Much better.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Just not enough to call me back. ARTHUR hesitant. Straining to keep the mania down.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I wanted to organize my thoughts. Before I called. That’s what I’ve been doing.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: And how’s that going?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Good. Very good. I just... (fighting the flood) I need to be more precise. That's (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 ARTHUR (cont'd) my goal. (he smiles) Speak softly and carry a big baguette. There’s a beat. Their history rushing in around them.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: As good as this feels, you know where it goes.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: No. You’re wrong. What feels so good is not knowing where it goes.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: How do I talk to you, Arthur? So you hear me? Like a child? Like a nut? Like everything’s fine? What’s the secret? Because I need you to hear me.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I hear everything.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Then hear this: You need help. Before this gets too far, you need help. You’ve got great cards here. You keep your clothes on, you can pretty much do any goddamn thing you want. You want out? You’re out. You wanna bake bread? Go with God. There’s one wrong answer in the whole pile and there you are with your arms around it.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I said I was sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You thought the hotel was overwhelming? You keep pissing on this case, they’re gonna cut you off at the knees.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Not a chance.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I just couldn’t get through to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What? You scared him to death? (ridiculous) The man was a bull. Never happen.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: So why does he fold?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: It’s got to be an accident. No note? Arthur without a note? Guy couldn’t take a piss without leaving a memo. It has to be an accident.  90

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don’t get that either. One minute he’s so pumped up he’s gonna take on the world, twelve hours later he’s sucking down pills? Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Why? Because people are fucking incomprehensible. Why... (waving the idea away) You live this long, you’re supposed to get something out of it. What did I get? I’m still horny and vain and afraid to die. What do I know about anything? (he drinks) Thirty years I know Arthur. Good years. And what I feel right now? If I’m honest? I can’t even say it it’s so awful.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Say it. (silence) That we caught a lucky break? MARTY looks over. Hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: We did, didn’t we? MICHAEL nods. They turn.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0S)
dialogues.text: Marty? BARRY behind them.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: We need to get up to the office.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: They accepted?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: In principle. Don Jeffries wants us on the phone in half an hour. (including Michael in this now--) I tried to explain about Arthur. They’re a little short on sympathy at this point.  91

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. U/North’s settling?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: They think there’s a window. They want to try. (just the messenger) It’s their show. What’re we gonna do? MICHAEL stunned. Silent.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You did what you could, Michael. We all did. (draining his drink) It is what it is. BARRY helping MARTY off the stool. Holding his coat.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: You need a ride?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No. No, I’m okay. MARTY with a misty wave good night. MICHAEL watching BARR navigate the old man out toward the door, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. THE PHONE RINGING. ANNA’S BIG SISTER padding in, turning on a light and --

dialogues.speaker: BIG SISTER
dialogues.text: (answering) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (PHONE/OVER)
dialogues.text: I’m looking for Anna Kysersun?

dialogues.speaker: BIG SISTER
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL on the sidewalk --

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL/PHONE
dialogues.text: My name is Michael Clayton. I’m an attorney in New York and I--

dialogues.speaker: BIG SISTER/PHONE
dialogues.text: Well you’ve got some nerve.  92

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL/ PHONE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: BIG SISTER/PHONE
dialogues.text: You get her all the way to New York and then leave her at the airport? This is not a complicated person! This is a girl who’s never been farther away from home than Milwaukee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL driving, as we hear -- MICHAEL/PHONE V.O. Wait a minute... BIG SISTER/PHONE V.O. No -- you wait! -- she’s coming home tomorrow! -- and when she does, if you call here again, I’m warning you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La Guardia in the background. THE MERCEDES pulling in as MICHAEL/PHONE V.O. -- hang -- hang on -- wait -- are you saying she’s in New York? -- she’s in New York, right now?

dialogues.speaker: BIG SISTER, (PHONE/OVER)
dialogues.text: This is a young girl! Do you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERNE and IKER watching MICHAEL get out of the Mercedes -

dialogues.speaker: IKER
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty. Quiet. MICHAEL knocking on a door.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Anna? (knocking harder) Anna?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (0S)
dialogues.text: (through the door) Who is it?  93

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Anna, my name is Michael Clayton. I’m a friend of Arthur’s. AS THE DOOR OPENS just a crack. ANNA standing there. A frightened small town girl in a strange place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERNE and IKER as they were. In the dark. Not happy.

dialogues.speaker: IKER
dialogues.text: What’re you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: VERNE
dialogues.text: I‘1l watch the door. Why don’t you give his car a good once over?

dialogues.speaker: IKER
dialogues.text: (as he gets out) How do I know I’m not getting home tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: ANNA sitting on the bed. Crying. MICHAEL in the room’s only chair.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: ..-he didn’t want to say exactly what it was, just that when I got here he would pick me up and show me and I would see that it was something that would win the whole case...even this morning I thought, okay, if I get to the airport and the ticket’s not there, then I'll know, okay, you’re stupid, now you can go home...but it was there and he paid like eight hundred dollars for a first class ticket, so I just, I got on the plane, I believed him... MICHAEL there for her. Probing very gently here.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You think maybe he was disappointed? Let’s say he knew that you’d told somebody else about all this. You think that might’ve, in some crazy way, that he’d be disappointed by that?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: But I didn’t.  94

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You must’ve told somebody.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No. He made me promise.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Nobody knew about this? You never told anybody?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No... (new tears welling) He really was crazy, wasn’t he? MICHAEL without an answer for that. Watching her cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queens. Midnight. Patrol cars parked outside. Couple cops changing shifts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NYPD ugly. GENE CLAYTON, shirtsleeves and shoulder holste tearing through A HUGE OLD FILING CABINET. HANDS pulling open the drawers. One after the next. Searching through t clutter of blank forms and department stationery. MICHAEL waiting by the door.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: (finally) You talking about these? He’s holding a stack of PROTECTIVE CRIME SCENE SEALS.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I only need one.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: You know what this is?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: You said a favor. This is more than a favor.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Nobody’s gonna know where it came from.  95

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Are you that jammed up?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What’re you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: It’s the restaurant, right? One of these guys you owe? “Get me a seal.”

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Do you really want to know? GENE hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go take a leak. You'll probably be gone when I get back. (he tosses the seals onto the table--) You know your way out. MICHAEL stands aside. GENE pushes past him and out the do MICHAEL waiting for him to walk away, as -- EXT. TRIBECA STREET/ARTHUR’S BUILDING -- NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two a.m. Dark and quiet. EXT. ARTHUR’S BUILDING/FRONT DOOR -- NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL with a crowbar. Pushing the door to the limits of the lock. Checking the street. Wedging the crowbar under the lock. Leaning. Now harder. And pushing, and... SNAP. He’s in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DOOR TO ARTHUR EDEN’S LOFT. It’s a mess. The metal frame is bent and splintered where the cops beat their wa in. The original lock has been destroyed and replaced by a short length of chain-link held to a padlock that’s bee screwed into the wall. A SEAL -- “Crime Scene Do Not Ente -- plastered like a big bandaid across the door and frame MICHAEL standing there. Listening to the silence. In his hand, the seal he took from Gene. Framing it -- making su he’1l be able to replace it perfectly. He will. Now he’s pulling the crowbar and --  96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. And then light, as THE DOOR falls open. MICHAEL at the threshold. Hesitating. Listening. Nervous. And then h steps in. Closing the door behind him, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a light comes on in Arthur’s loft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERNE and IKER. It’s their POV. Two grim faces.

dialogues.speaker: IKER
dialogues.text: This just gets better and better. (Verne just staring up at that window-- ) What’re we doing? VERNE doesn’t answer. Checks his watch. Looks back up to the window. Lots of ugly wheels turning, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME CUTS -- MICHAEL searching -- moving quietly through the space. He’s not really sure what he’s looking for, so everything’s important. -- MICHAEL flipping through stacks of newspapers. -- MICHAEL checking a pile of photography books. -- MICHAEL at a wall covered with pictures of farms. -- MICHAEL staring at the baguettes piled on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL at the threshold. Knowing this is where it happen Creeped out. Turning away and -- There on the floor. Arthur’s coat. MICHAEL kneeling to pick up the coat. Stopping suddenly. Something much more interesting there beside it -- “REALM AND CONQUEST” Book One. The red cover. MICHAEL just stunned. Stalled. Confused.  97 CLOSE-UP -- THE BOOK as he begins to flip the pages. And we've never seen the text before. There are illustrations at the start of every chapter. Line drawings depicting th dramatic high points of an epic quest. Chapter One: The Avian Warriors. Chapter Two: Exile of The Deserters. Chapter Three: Summons To Conquest. Arthur has clearly read these first three chapters. Whole passages are underlined. Notes scrawled here and there in the margins. Pages folded back. And then -- A BOOKMARK falls out. Fluttering down to the floor. MICHAEL reaches down to pick it up. CLOSE-UP -- THE BOOKMARK. It’s a receipt. “COPY MASTERS -- YOUR ONE STOP FOR COPIES” MICHAEL staring at the receipt. Then the book. Then the receipt. Then --

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0S)
dialogues.text: Freeze! -- MICHAEL -- totally -- completely startled --

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0S)
dialogues.text: (it’s behind him) -- right there asshole! -- get your hands up! -- now! -- NOW! -- MICHAEL -- okay -- don’t shoot -- raise hands --

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (coming closer) -- what’s in your hand? -- drop it! --

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: -- it’s just -- it’s a book! --

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: -- drop it! -- turn around slowly! -- who else is here? -- MICHAEL drops the book. Turning around slowly as the SOUN OF A POLICE RADIO begins to rattle and -- TWO YOUNG NERVOUS POLICE OFFICERS -- guns drawn -- coming from the open door --

dialogues.speaker: COP/VOICE
dialogues.text: -- I said, who else is here? --  98

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: -- nobody, I’m alone -- CoP (to his partner) -- check in there -- these closets -- (to Michael) You move I’1ll take your head off! MICHAEL frozen like that and the TWO NERVOUS COPS circlin around him and POLICE RADIO CHATTER rising and the big st of a terrible mistake wafting through the air, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL alone with a cold cup of coffee. Staring at himse in the one-way mirror. Waiting. Finally, THE DOOR opens -

dialogues.speaker: DET. DALBERTO
dialogues.text: We need the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DALBERTO walking off. MICHAEL emerges from the questionin room. GENE waiting for him. Absolutely furious. He wants to scream but can’t. Waiting for DALBERTO to disappear --

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: So you know, I now owe this scumbag and his wife -- who’s a total piece of shit in my unit -- now I owe them my balls for this.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Gene. You know I am.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: “Nobody’s gonna know it’s me.” (you asshole) You know what happens he doesn’t bury this? That I gave you this thing?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s bad.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I’m eighteen months away from my twenty! You just put my pension in jeopardy!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You made your point.  99

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: It’s not a point!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Who called 911?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: The building’s empty. I was quiet. I was there maybe six minutes. Who called it in? Does that make sense to you, that happening like-- GENE grabbing him -- jerking him close --

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: This never happened. MICHAEL hesitates. Nods. Impatient -- he pushes back -- hard -- breaks Gene’s grip. Brothers. Toe-to-toe.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: All these cops think you’re a lawyer. Then you got all these lawyers thinking you’re some kind of cop. You've got everybody fooled, right? Everybody but you. You know exactly what you are. MICHAEL just taking it. GENE backing away. Turning, and n he’s walking... Gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. NYU Students swarming the sidewalks. “COPY MASTERS -- YOUR ONE STOP FOR COPIES!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big college operation. MICHAEL at the counter watching A COPY KID coming from the back with a heavy cardboard bo Straining it to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: COPY KID
dialogues.text: We tried to call like six times, I guess your answering machine is messed up or something. We took a shot... (opening the box) We ran out of red covers. (handing one over) We only had two thousand in stock, so the other thousand we did in blue.  MICHAEL doesn’t answer because --

dialogues.speaker: IN HIS HAND
dialogues.text: A BOOKLET. A bright red plastic cover. The title:

dialogues.speaker: SUMMONS TO CONQUEST
dialogues.text: And when he flips it open. There it is, the by-now-famili UNITED-NORTHFIELD MEMO #229 in all it’s ugly splendor. MICHAEL reading the memo. Lost in it. As we watch the realization take shape -- how dangerous...how sensitive.. how threatening these few sheets of paper must be.

dialogues.speaker: COPY KID
dialogues.text: (Michael still reading) It’s okay, right? MICHAEL looks up. Dazed.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What? Yeah. It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: COPY KID
dialogues.text: You got a van or... (sensing confusion) There’s like ten boxes.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Right. (forcing himself to rally here--) Look, I‘11 tell you what... (finding his wallet) I‘1l give you fifty bucks to keep the rest till the end of the week. COPY KID smiles. Sure. MICHAEL grabbing that one box on t counter. Turning away to exit and -- IKER standing there. Next in line. Watching him go --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DON JEFFRIES walking with Karen’s two assistants, MAUDE a TODD and several U/NORTH EXECUTIVES toward the Kenner, Ba Ledeen offices. KAREN on a phone call, falling behind --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (calling to the group) Don! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAREN (cont'd) (he turns back) You guys go ahead. I1/’11 catch up. And they do. And KAREN stops there. Turns -- EXT. KAREN’S POV/ACROSS THE PLAZA -- DAY (CONT) VERNE waiting. Watching her come. Not a happy reunion.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? You were leaving...

dialogues.speaker: VERNE
dialogues.text: Do you know Michael Clayton?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: From the... Yes. Why ~”

dialogues.speaker: VERNE
dialogues.text: We have a situation. He hands her A RED COVERED BOOKLET. Calmly checking the perimeter as she opens it and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER RED BOOKLET. This one in MICHAEL’S HAND. This one in motion because he’s walking and -- WE’RE TRACKING WITH HIM Power central. Normally it’s quiet and subdued up here, b the combination of Arthur’s death the night before and th sudden paroxysm of activity on the U/North settlement see to have drawn a crowd. MICHAEL heading briskly for the central reception atrium, passing ATTORNEYS and SUPPORT S clustered along the way. There’s A WEEPY GROUP bunched ne Arthur’s office and --

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: (as Michael goes by) Did they find you?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: Marty. (pointing around the corner and--) I don’t think they went down yet... MICHAEL moving around the corner and into --

dialogues.speaker: THIRTY PEOPLE
dialogues.text: scrambling over STACKS OF PRESENTATION DOCUMENTS -- this stuff was supposed to be ready for the U/North meeting an there’s been some sort of clerical fuck up. So now there’ twenty-five opinions on how to fix it and fifteen conversations going and nine cell phones ringing and six people on their knees going through the pages and --

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: (on a mobile phone in the middle of it all--) -- so either we cap the interest on the primary trust or somebody figures out how to split the custody fees -- (spotting Michael) -- the audit’s mandatory, right? -- (covering the phone, calling back over his shoulder--) -- Marty! -- (then the phone- -- no, just hang on (then to Michael--) -- he’s been looking for you -- (then back to the phone, as--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL crosses the chaos to the elevator bank and --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Your phone is off. There’s too much going on for your phone to be off.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I need a minute.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (impatient, tired) Yeah well, now we’re late, so...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: We never got to finish last night.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What’d you do? Close the place? You look like hell.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I left right after you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you say so. (checking his watch) We’ve been here all night. We had to make an announcement. (turning now--) Jean! Jeannie! (calling to his Assistant across the way--) Where’s the thing? The envelope? (back to Michael) So I wanted your input, but I couldn’t get you and I had to pull the trigger. I put Bob Nast and Kim -- which is probably a mistake -- they’re gonna try to pull together a memorial service by the end of the week. I told them to call you if they need help, okay? (distracted now because Jean’s holding something up for him to see--) -- no, no, the other one -- (back to Michael) So we cut a check for you this morning, but there’s some strings attached. And Barry, there’s no way around it, he’s got to be involved.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What if Arthur was onto something?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Onto what? MICHAEL hesitating because here’s JEAN, tapping her watch MARTY to hurry up as she hands him A SMALL GRAY ENVELOPE

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: U/North. What if Arthur wasn’t just crazy? What if he was right?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Right about what? That we're on the wrong side?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Wrong side. Wrong way. All of it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: This is news? We’re defending cancer for crissake. The case reeked from Day One. Fifteen years in, I’ve got to tell you how we pay the rent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would they do, though, if they thought Arthur was gonna go public?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What would they do? Are you fucking soft? They’re doing it! (honestly incredulous) We don’t straighten this settlement out in the next twenty-four hours, they’re gonna withhold nine million dollars in fees they owe us. Then they’re gonna pull out the video of Arthur’s flashdance in Milwaukee and sue us for legal malpractice, except there won’t be anything to win because by that point the merger with London will be dead and we'll be selling off the furniture. (handing Michael the envelope now--) That’s eighty. We’re calling it a bonus. You’re getting a three year contract at your current numbers. That’s assuming this all works out. And now, before MICHAEL can get his footing, here comes -

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: (the envelope) You’re doing this now?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (the documents) Are they ready?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Almost. They're proofing. (to Michael) ) Look, I agreed to this, okay? But there’s rules now. You want the contract, you’re signing a confidentiality agreement and it’s gonna be retroactive and it’s gonna be bulletproof. Because Marty’s too nice to say it, but with everything you know about this place and the clients and the people who work here, it makes things just a little too weird when you come in and ask for eighty grand. A nasty beat. MICHAEL stung. Roiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was gonna shake anybody down, Barry, I’d come right to you. And it wouldn’t be for eighty grand. (to Marty) Is this him or you?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Hey, if I’m wrong, I apologize.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You’re wrong. You’re way-the-fuck wrong.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: So there you go.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Enough. Okay? Everybody. (to Michael) He’s an asshole. But he knows it. (to Barry) And you’re on the record. Okay? (to both) Everybody happy? Nobody’s happy. And here’s JEAN with a nudge --

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Don Jeffries is in the conference room...

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Okay, we’re coming... (to Barry) Tell them to bring the paperwork down when they’re ready. (to Michael) Call Bob Nast, just see if they need help with this thing... (starting to walk away, then he stops, turns back--) You’re welcome. MICHAEL standing there, with THE ENVELOPE in one hand and THE RED BOOKLET in the other. Standing there watching MAR and BARRY hustle away. All the power, all the oxygen, leaving with them. The moment passing, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minutes later. Crowded. MICHAEL, looking shaky, fleeing the office. And the door opens and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL stepping off the elevator. KAREN only a few feet away. She’s waiting to step onto another elevator car tha also arrived. They pass within a yards of each other. Bot of them wrapped so tight just now they never even know it EXT. “TIM'S” -- NIGHT Dark and forlorn. As we hear --

dialogues.speaker: VERNE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Mercedes puts this little tag...

dialogues.speaker: IKER, (OVER)
dialogues.text: yeah, they shield that cable...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parked down the block. IKER on the driver’s side. VERNE beside him, holding a schematic drawing. Several bags and boxes in the back and --

dialogues.speaker: VERNE
dialogues.text: +..there’s room here for the kel... (the schematic) ...once you tap into his GPS just make sure it’s flush, we're packing the charge in the backseat armrest.

dialogues.speaker: IKER
dialogues.text: Can I see it? (Verne opens the box, very carefully--) Could you make it any uglier?

dialogues.speaker: VERNE
dialogues.text: It’s a work of art.

dialogues.speaker: IKER
dialogues.text: Who makes this?

dialogues.speaker: VERNE
dialogues.text: Russian mafia. Albanians trying to look like Russian mafia. It’s as far from the other thing as we can get. IKER nods. VERNE carefully taking the box back. INT. “TIM'S” BAR/DINING ROOM -- NIGHT MICHAEL sitting on the bar watching ZABEL open a bank envelope. Just the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said twelve... (check in hand) This is seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Don’t get too excited. (a bottle of vodka) You want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: ZABEL
dialogues.text: I’m working. (watching Michael serve himself) So we’re square then. No bad blood.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Just doing your job, right?

dialogues.speaker: ZABEL
dialogues.text: That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Everybody’s got a job to do.

dialogues.speaker: ZABEL
dialogues.text: Like it or not, right?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Like it or not. ZABEL walks. MICHAEL alone in the dark, dead bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A basement hideaway on a slow night. We’re back where we started. MICHAEL at the table with THE PLUMBER, THE DEALE and THE TWO OTHER PLAYERS.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: I go like that. Check. THE PLUMBER starting to peel bills off his flashroll, as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chinatown late. Cold. Quiet. IKER walking up to THE MERCEDES. He’s holding a remote unit. Pressing it once. Nothing. Again. Nothing. Third time’s the charm. Lights flashing as the alarm disables and --  108

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAREN CROWDER -- exactly where we first met her -- sittin fully dressed on the john. Hiding here. Trying to fight off a panic attack using a breathing exercise she read ab in an airline magazine. Losing the battle, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
